title: 109_hr206
content: Clean-fuel credit for businesses in nonattainment areas is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The clean-fuel credit for eligible businesses includes the clean-fuel property credit and the clean-burning fuel use credit. The clean-fuel property credit consists of qualified vehicle property costs and qualified refueling property costs. Qualified vehicle property costs refer to expenses for qualified clean-fuel vehicle property placed in service during the taxable year. The clean-fuel credit for eligible businesses includes the clean-fuel property credit for qualified vehicle property costs and qualified refueling property costs. The credit is limited based on the type of motor vehicle, with maximum amounts ranging from $2,000 to $50,000 depending on the vehicle's specifications. The term 'qualified clean-fuel vehicle property' is defined as per section 179A(c), excluding vehicles propelled by non-clean-burning fuels. 'Qualified refueling property costs' refer to expenses related to refueling property for eligible businesses. The term 'qualified refueling property costs' refers to expenses incurred by eligible businesses for clean-fuel vehicle refueling property placed in service in a nonattainment area during the taxable year. There is a limitation on the aggregate cost that can be taken into account, which is the lesser of $100,000 or the cost of the property. The cost of the property is reduced by the amount previously taken into account under different clauses for preceding taxable years and with respect to property placed in service. The clean-burning fuel use credit is 50 cents for each gasoline gallon equivalent of clean-burning fuel used by an eligible business to propel qualified clean-fuel vehicle property. The term 'clean-burning fuel' is defined accordingly. Special rules from section 179A(b)(2) apply. The term 'clean-burning fuel' is defined as compressed natural gas and biodiesel, with a gasoline gallon equivalent determined by the Secretary. An eligible business is defined as a qualified business entity or proprietorship in nonattainment areas. The tax credit for clean-fuel vehicles is applicable to businesses in nonattainment areas, as defined by the Clean Air Act. The credit cannot be claimed if a deduction or credit is already allowed for the same expense. This credit is now part of the general business credit. The tax credit for clean-fuel vehicles in nonattainment areas is now part of the general business credit. A denial of double benefit is implemented for clean-burning fuel expenses, with the credit allowed against regular and minimum tax. The tax credit for clean-fuel vehicles in nonattainment areas is now part of the general business credit. Special rules apply for the clean fuels credit, with separate application of sections 39 and the credit, and limitations on the credit allowed under subsection (a). The clean fuels credit is now part of the general business credit, with specific rules and limitations on the credit allowed under subsection (a). Conforming amendments have been made to include the clean fuels credit in relevant sections of the tax code. The tax code has been amended to include the clean fuels credit as part of the general business credit, with specific rules and limitations. Amendments have been made to various sections to incorporate the clean fuels credit. The clean-fuel credit for businesses in nonattainment areas is effective for property placed in service after December 31, 2004.
